title: Errors-in-Variables Regression
text: Error--variables (EIV) models useful tools account measurement error independent variable. studies agreement, particularly useful paired measurements paired measurements (X & Y) underlying value (e.g., two assays analyte). Deming regression one simplest forms EIV models promoted W. Edwards Deming1. first detail method Adcock (1878) followed Kummell (1879) Koopmans (1936). name comes popularity Deming’s book (Deming 1943), within field clinical chemistry, procedure simply referred “Deming regression” (e.g., Linnet (1990)).

title: Errors-in-Variables Regression
text: can start creating fake data work . Also, assume, based historical data, measurement error ratio equal 2. data can run dem_reg function results printed. resulting regression line can plotted.
code: library(SimplyAgree)  dat = data.frame(   x = c(7, 8.3, 10.5, 9, 5.1, 8.2, 10.2, 10.3, 7.1, 5.9),   y = c(7.9, 8.2, 9.6, 9, 6.5, 7.3, 10.2, 10.6, 6.3, 5.2) ) dem1 = dem_reg(y ~ x,                data = dat,                error.ratio = 2,                weighted = FALSE) dem1 #> Deming Regression with 95% C.I.  #>  #> Call: #> dem_reg(formula = y ~ x, data = dat, weighted = FALSE, error.ratio = 2,  #>     conf.level = 0.95) #>  #> Coefficients: #> (Intercept)           x  #>      0.1285      0.9745 plot(dem1, interval = "confidence")

title: Errors-in-Variables Regression
text: assumptions Deming regression model, primarily normality homogeneity variance, can checked check method Deming regression results. plots appear fine regards assumptions.
code: check(dem1)

title: Errors-in-Variables Regression
text: fitting Deming regression model, can extract estimated true values residuals. fitted() function returns estimated true Y values, accounting measurement error. residuals() function returns optimized residuals default, correspond perpendicular distances point regression line.

title: Errors-in-Variables Regression
text: example, rely upon “ferritin” data deming R package. Let demonstrate problem using simple Deming regression weights helpful. look two plots , can see severe problem using “un-weighted” model.   Now, let us see happens weighted set TRUE.   weighted model provides better fit.
code: library(deming) data('ferritin')  head(ferritin) #>   id period old.lot new.lot #> 1  1      1       1       1 #> 2  2      1       3       3 #> 3  3      1      10       9 #> 4  4      1      13      11 #> 5  5      1      13      12 #> 6  6      1      15      13 dem2 = dem_reg(   old.lot ~ new.lot,   data = ferritin,   weighted = FALSE ) summary(dem2) #> Deming Regression with 95% C.I.  #>  #> Call: #> dem_reg(formula = old.lot ~ new.lot, data = ferritin, weighted = FALSE,  #>     conf.level = 0.95) #>  #> Coefficients: #>             coef      bias      se  df lower.ci upper.ci      t p.value #> Intercept 5.2157 -0.235818 2.18603 160   0.8985    9.533  2.386 0.01821 #> Slope     0.9637  0.002597 0.02505 160   0.9143    1.013 -1.448 0.14949 #>  #> 160 degrees of freedom #> Error variance ratio (lambda): 1.0000  plot(dem2) check(dem2) dem3 = dem_reg(   old.lot ~ new.lot,   data = ferritin,   weighted = TRUE ) summary(dem3) #> Weighted Deming Regression with 95% C.I.  #>  #> Call: #> dem_reg(formula = old.lot ~ new.lot, data = ferritin, weighted = TRUE,  #>     conf.level = 0.95) #>  #> Coefficients: #>               coef       bias       se  df lower.ci upper.ci       t   p.value #> Intercept -0.02616  0.0065148 0.033219 160 -0.09176  0.03945 -0.7874 4.322e-01 #> Slope      1.03052 -0.0001929 0.006262 160  1.01815  1.04288  4.8729 2.626e-06 #>  #> 160 degrees of freedom #> Error variance ratio (lambda): 1.0000  plot(dem3) check(dem3)

title: Errors-in-Variables Regression
text: Passing-Bablok regression robust, nonparametric alternative Deming regression method comparison studies (passing1983?). Unlike Deming regression, makes assumptions distribution measurement errors. method estimates slope shifted median pairwise slopes data points, makes resistant outliers.

title: Errors-in-Variables Regression
text: Passing-Bablok regression particularly useful : X Y measured error want robust method sensitive outliers relationship assumed linear X Y highly positively correlated

title: Errors-in-Variables Regression
text: pb_reg() function implements three variants Passing-Bablok regression: “scissors” (default): robust, scale-invariant method (bablok1988?) “symmetric”: Original method (passing1983?) “invariant”: Scale-invariant method (passing1984?)
code: # Create example data pb_data <- data.frame(   method1 = c(69.3, 27.1, 61.3, 50.8, 34.4, 92.3, 57.5, 45.5, 33.3, 60.9,               56.3, 49.9, 89.7, 28.9, 96.3, 76.6, 83.2, 79.4, 51.7, 32.5,               99.1, 14.2, 84.1, 48.8, 61.5, 84.9, 93.2, 73.8, 62.1, 98.6),   method2 = c(69.1, 26.7, 61.4, 51.2, 34.7, 88.5, 57.9, 45.1, 33.4, 60.8,               66.5, 48.2, 88.3, 29.3, 96.4, 77.1, 82.7, 78.9, 51.6, 28.8,               98.4, 12.7, 83.6, 47.3, 61.2, 84.6, 92.1, 73.4, 61.9, 98.6) )  # Fit Passing-Bablok regression pb1 <- pb_reg(method2 ~ method1, data = pb_data) #> Warning in pb_reg(method2 ~ method1, data = pb_data): Bootstrap confidence #> intervals are recommended for 'invariant' and 'scissors' methods. Consider #> setting replicates > 0. pb1 #> Passing-Bablok (scissors) with 95% C.I.  #>  #> Call: #> pb_reg(formula = method2 ~ method1, data = pb_data) #>  #> Coefficients: #> (Intercept)     method1  #>     0.09622     0.99440  #>  #> Kendall's Tau (H0: tau <= 0): #>   tau:       0.9632 #>   p-value:   0.0000 #>  #> CUSUM Linearity Test: #>   Test stat: 1.0000 #>   p-value:   0.1844

title: Errors-in-Variables Regression
text: summary provides details regression coefficients diagnostic tests: plot() method displays regression line data:
code: summary(pb1) #> Passing-Bablok (scissors) with 95% C.I.  #>  #> Call: #> pb_reg(formula = method2 ~ method1, data = pb_data) #>  #> Coefficients: #>        term    coef       se lower.ci upper.ci df null_value reject_h0 #> 1 Intercept 0.09622 0.390603  -0.7206   0.8105 28          0     FALSE #> 2   method1 0.99440 0.005918   0.9840   1.0072 28          1     FALSE #>  #> 28 degrees of freedom #> Error variance ratio (lambda): 1.0000 plot(pb1)

title: Errors-in-Variables Regression
text: check() method provides diagnostic plots specific Passing-Bablok regression, including CUSUM linearity test Kendall’s tau correlation:
code: check(pb1)

title: Errors-in-Variables Regression
text: robust inference, especially “invariant” “scissors” methods, bootstrap confidence intervals recommended:
code: pb2 <- pb_reg(method2 ~ method1,                data = pb_data,                replicates = 999) summary(pb2) #> Passing-Bablok (scissors) with 95% C.I.  #>  #> Call: #> pb_reg(formula = method2 ~ method1, data = pb_data, replicates = 999) #>  #> Coefficients: #>        term    coef       se lower.ci upper.ci df null_value reject_h0 #> 1 Intercept 0.09622 0.088205 -0.09182   0.2539 28          0     FALSE #> 2   method1 0.99440 0.001291  0.99198   0.9970 28          1      TRUE #>  #> 28 degrees of freedom #> Error variance ratio (lambda): 1.0000 #>  #>  #> Bootstrap CIs based on 999 resamples

title: Errors-in-Variables Regression
text: theoretically valid, still experimental, enhancement dem_reg pb_reg functions addition joint confidence regions slope intercept parameters. Traditional confidence intervals treat parameter separately, regression analysis, parameters correlated. Joint confidence regions account correlation creating elliptical region (intercept, slope) parameter space. approach, promoted Sadler (2010), provides several advantages: Higher Statistical Power: ellipse typically requires 20-50% fewer samples traditional confidence intervals detect bias Accounts Parameter Correlation: measurement range narrow, slope intercept highly negatively correlated Appropriate Test: Testing point (e.g., slope=1, intercept=0) naturally done region, separate intervals power advantage pronounced ratio maximum minimum X values small (< 10:1), common clinical method comparisons.

title: Errors-in-Variables Regression
text: plot_joint() function allows visualization confidence region parameter space:  plot shows: red ellipse: Joint confidence region blue rectangle: Traditional confidence intervals black dot: Estimated (intercept, slope) green/red X: Ideal point (whether enclosed ) Notice ellipse smaller rectangle, especially directions matter detecting bias. Passing-Bablok regression, bootstrap resampling must used obtain variance-covariance matrix needed joint confidence region:
code: plot_joint(dem1,             ideal_slope = 1,             ideal_intercept = 0,            show_intervals = TRUE) plot_joint(pb2)

title: Errors-in-Variables Regression
text: joint_test() function provides formal hypothesis test whether identity line (slope = 1, intercept = 0) falls within joint confidence region: returns htest object Mahalanobis distance (chi-squared statistic) p-value. test can also applied Passing-Bablok models fitted bootstrap:

title: Errors-in-Variables Regression
text: Deming regression assumes paired measures (\(x_i, \space  y_i\)) measured error. \[ x_i = X_i + \epsilon_i \] \[ y_i = Y_i + \delta_i \] can measure relationship two variables following model. \[ \hat Y_i = \beta_0 + \beta_1 \cdot \hat X_i \] Traditionally 2 null hypotheses. First, intercept equal zero: \[ H_0: \beta_0 = 0 \space vs. \space H_1: \beta_0 \ne 0 \] Second, slope equal one: \[ H_0: \beta_1 = 1 \space vs. \space H_1: \beta_0 \ne 1 \]

title: Errors-in-Variables Regression
text: joint \((1-\alpha) \times 100\%\) confidence region \((\beta_0, \beta_1)\) defined : \[ (\hat{\beta} - \beta_0)^T V^{-1} (\hat{\beta} - \beta_0) \leq \chi^2_{2,\alpha} \] : \(\hat{\beta}\) = estimated parameters \((\hat{\beta}_0, \hat{\beta}_1)\) \(\beta_0\) = hypothesized parameters (e.g., \((0, 1)\) identity) \(V\) = variance-covariance matrix \(\chi^2_{2,\alpha}\) = chi-square critical value 2 degrees freedom forms ellipse parameter space accounts correlation slope intercept.

title: Errors-in-Variables Regression
text: Deming regression model also assumes measurement error (\(\sigma^2\)) ratio constant. \[ \lambda = \frac{\sigma^2_\epsilon}{\sigma^2_\delta} \] SimplyAgree, error ratio can set error.ratio argument. defaults 1, can changed user. replicate measures taken, user can use id argument indicate measures belong subject/participant. measurement error, error ratio, estimated data . data measured replicate error ratio (\(\lambda\)) can estimated coefficient variation (data available) mean x y (\(\bar x, \space \bar y\)). \[ \lambda = \frac{(CV_y \cdot \bar y)^2}{(CV_x \cdot \bar x)^2} \]

title: Errors-in-Variables Regression
text: cases variance X Y may increase proportional true value measure. cases, may prudent use “weighted” Deming regression models. weights used SimplyAgree suggested Linnet (1993). \[ \hat w_i = \frac{1}{ [ \frac{x_i + \lambda \cdot y_i}{1 + \lambda}]^2} \] Weights can also provided weights argument. weighted Deming regression selected (weighted = FALSE), weights observation equal 1. estimated mean X Y estimated following. \[ \bar x_w =  \frac{\Sigma^{N}_{=1} \hat w_i \cdot x_i}{\Sigma^{N}_{=1} \hat w_i} \] \[ \bar y_w =  \frac{\Sigma^{N}_{=1} \hat w_i \cdot y_i}{\Sigma^{N}_{=1} \hat w_i} \]

title: Errors-in-Variables Regression
text: First, 3 components (\(v_x, \space v_y, \space cov_{xy}\)) \[ v_x = \Sigma_{=1}^N \space \hat w_i \cdot (x_i- \bar x_w)^2 \] \[ v_y = \Sigma_{=1}^N \space \hat w_i \cdot (y_i- \bar y_w)^2 \] \[ cov_{xy} = \Sigma_{=1}^N \space \hat w_i \cdot  (x_i- \bar x_w) \cdot (y_i- \bar y_w) \] slope (\(b_1\)) can estimated following equation. \[ b_1 = \frac{(\lambda \cdot v_y - v_x) + \sqrt{(v_x-\lambda \cdot v_y)^2 + 4 \cdot \lambda \cdot cov_{xy}^2}}{2 \cdot \lambda \cdot cov_{xy}} \] intercept (\(b_0\)) can estimated following equation. \[ b_0 = \bar y_w - b_1 \cdot \bar x_w \] standard errors b1 b0 estimated using jackknife method (detailed Linnet (1990)).

title: Agreement Tests
text: reported limits agreement derived work Bland Altman (1986) Bland Altman (1999). title: Agreement Tests
text: Step 1: Calculate Individual Subject Means Variances \[ \bar x_i = \frac{1}{n_{xi}} \Sigma_{j=1}^{n_{xi}} x_{ij} \] \[ \bar y_i = \frac{1}{n_{yi}} \Sigma_{j=1}^{n_{yi}} y_{ij} \] \[ \bar d_i = \bar x_i - \bar y_i \] \[ \bar d = \Sigma_{=1}^{n}\frac{d_i}{n} \] \[ s_{xi}^2 = \Sigma_{j=1}^{n_{xi}} \frac{(x_{xj}- \bar x_i)^2}{n_{xi}-1} \] \[ s_{yi}^2 = \Sigma_{j=1}^{n_{yi}} \frac{(y_{ij}- \bar y_i)^2}{n_{yi}-1} \] \[ s_{\bar d}^2 = \Sigma_{j=1}^{n} \frac{(d_{}- \bar d)^2}{n-1} \] Step 2: Compute pooled estimates within subject errors \[ s^2_{xw} = \Sigma_{=1}^{n} [\frac{n_{xi} -1}{N_x -1} \cdot s^2_{xi}] \] \[ s^2_{yw} = \Sigma_{=1}^{n} [\frac{n_{yi} -1}{N_y -1} \cdot s^2_{yi}] \] Step 3: Compute Harmonic Means Replicates \[ m_{xh} = \frac{n}{\Sigma_{=1}^n \frac{1}{n_{xi}}} \] \[ m_{yh} = \frac{n}{\Sigma_{=1}^n \frac{1}{n_{yi}}} \] Step 4: Compute variance differences \[ s^2_d = s^2_{\bar d} + (1+\frac{1}{m_{xh}}) \cdot s^2_{xw} + (1+\frac{1}{m_{yh}}) \cdot s^2_{yw} \] Step 5: Compute MOVER Components \[ S_{11} = s_{\bar d}^2 \cdot (1 - \frac{n-1}{\chi^2_{(1-\alpha, n-1)}}) \] \[ S_{12} = (1-\frac{1}{m_{xh}}) \cdot (1 - \frac{N_x-n}{\chi^2_{(1-\alpha, N_x-n)}}) \cdot s^2_{xw} \] \[ S_{13} = (1-\frac{1}{m_{yh}}) \cdot (1 - \frac{N_y-n}{\chi^2_{(1-\alpha, N_y-n)}}) \cdot s^2_{yw} \] \[ S_1 = \sqrt{S_{11}^2 +S_{12}^2 +S_{13}^2} \] \[ l = s_d^2 - S_1 \] \[ u = s_d^2 + S_1 \] \[ LME = \sqrt{\frac{z^2_{\alpha} \cdot s_d^2}{n} + z^2_{\beta/2} \cdot(\sqrt{u} - \sqrt{s^2_d})^2} \] \[ RME = \sqrt{\frac{z^2_{\alpha} \cdot s_d^2}{n} + z^2_{\beta/2} \cdot(\sqrt{l} - \sqrt{s^2_d})^2} \] ### LoA \[ LoA_{lower} = \bar d - z_{\beta/2} \cdot s_d \] \[ LoA_{upper} = \bar d + z_{\beta/2} \cdot s_d \]

title: Agreement Tests
text: Step 1: Compute mean variance \[ \bar d_i = \Sigma_{j=1}^{n_i} \frac{d_{ij}}{n_i} \] \[ \bar d = \Sigma^{n}_{=1} \frac{d_i}{n} \] \[ s_i^2 = \Sigma_{j=1}^{n_i} \frac{(d_{ij} - \bar d_i)^2}{n_i-1} \] Step 2: Compute pooled estimate within subject error \[ s_{dw}^2 = \Sigma_{=1}^{n} [\frac{n_i-1}{N-n} \cdot s_i^2] \] Step 3: Compute pooled estimate subject error \[ s^2_b = \Sigma_{=1}^n \frac{ (\bar d_i - \bar d)^2}{n-1} \] Step 4: Compute harmonic mean replicate size \[ m_h = \frac{n}{\Sigma_{=1}^n m_i^{-1}} \] Step 5: Compute SD difference \[ s_d^2 = s^2_b + (1+m_h^{-1}) \cdot s_{dw}^2 \] Step 6: Calculate l u \[ l = s_d^2 - \sqrt{[s_d^2 \cdot (1 - \frac{n-1}{\chi^2_{(1-\alpha, n-1)}})]^2+[(1-m_h^{-1}) \cdot (1- \frac{N-n}{\chi^2_{(1-\alpha, N-n)}})]^2} \] \[ u = s_d^2 + \sqrt{[s_d^2 \cdot (1 - \frac{n-1}{\chi^2_{(1-\alpha, n-1)}})]^2+[(1-m_h^{-1}) \cdot (1- \frac{N-n}{\chi^2_{(1-\alpha, N-n)}})]^2} \] Step 7: Compute LME RME \[ LME = \sqrt{\frac{z_{\alpha} \cdot s_d^2}{n} + z_{\beta/2}^2 \cdot (\sqrt{u}-\sqrt{s^2_d} )^2} \] \[ RME = \sqrt{\frac{z_{\alpha} \cdot s_d^2}{n} + z_{\beta/2}^2 \cdot (\sqrt{l}-\sqrt{s^2_d} )^2} \]

title: Agreement & Tolerance Limits
text: Francq, Berger, Boachie (2020) pose question paper published Statistics Medicine. Traditionally, working medicine physiology defaulted calculating form “limits agreement” Bland Altman (1986) recommended seminal paper. recommendation Bland Altman (1986) approximation, undergone many modifications (e.g., Bland Altman 1999; Zou 2011) improve accuracy agreement interval associated confidence intervals. Meanwhile, field industrial statistics focused calculating tolerance limits. R packages, tolerance R package available CRAN, entirely dedicated calculating tolerance limits. important note tolerance limited normal distribution can applied distributions (please see tolerance package Young (2010) details). However, agreement studies typically seen medicine, tolerance limits may accurate way determining whether two measurements adequately close one another. quote Francq, Berger, Boachie (2020): terms terminology, tolerance means, context, difference methods tolerated (measurements still comparable practice). Furthermore, tolerance interval exact therefore appropriate agreement interval. package, tolerance limits refer “tolerance” associated prediction interval difference 2 measurements. calculative approach (detailed much ) involves calculating prediction interval difference two methods (.e., estimate interval future observation fall, certain probability, given already observed) calculating confidence interval (.e., tolerance). Therefore, want 95% prediction interval 95% tolerance limits, calculating interval 95% future observations (prediction) 5% probability (1-tolerance) “true” prediction interval limits greater/less upper/lower tolerance limits. Personally, find use prediction intervals tolerance limits attractive 2 reasons: 1) coverage prediction intervals tolerance limits often better confidence intervals agreement limits, 2) interpretation tolerance limits much clearer. greater discussion topic, please see manuscript Francq, Berger, Boachie (2020) check R package BivRegBLS.

text: model fit, estimated marginal means (EMM), associated standard errors (SEM), calculated based gls fit model using emmeans. standard error prediction (SEP) EMM calculated using SEM residual standard error model (formula ). \[ SEP = \sqrt{SEM^2 + S^2_{residual} } \] SEP calculated, prediction interval can calculated following: \[ PI = EMM \pm t_{1-\alpha/2, df} \cdot SEP \] NOTE: degrees freedom (df) calculated using approximation Satterthwaite (1946) (see Kuznetsova, Brockhoff, Christensen (2017) explanation implementation R).

title: Agreement & Tolerance Limits

title: Agreement & Tolerance Limits
text: reported limits agreement derived work Bland Altman (1986) Bland Altman (1999). LoA \[ LoA = \bar d \pm z_{1-(1-agree)/2} \cdot S_d \] wherein \(z_{1-(1-agree)/2}\) value normal distribution given agreement level (default 95%), \(\bar d\) mean differences, \(S_d\) standard deviations differences. Confidence Interval Calculate variance LoA \[ S_{LoA} = S_d \cdot \sqrt{\frac{1}{N}+ \frac{z^2_{1-(1-agree)/2}}{2 \cdot(N-1)} } \] Calculate Left Moving Estimator Bland-Altman Method \[ LME = t_{1 - \alpha, \space df} \cdot S_{LoA} \] MOVER Method \[ LME = S_d \cdot \sqrt{\frac{z_{1-\alpha}^2}{N} + z^2_{1-agree} \cdot (\sqrt{\frac{df}{\chi^2_{\alpha,df}}}-1)^2} \] Calculate Confidence Interval \[ Lower \space LoA \space C.. = Lower \space LoA - LME \] \[ Upper \space LoA \space C.. = Upper \space LoA + LME \]

title: Agreement & Tolerance Limits
text: Compute mean variance \[ \bar d_i = \Sigma_{j=1}^{n_i} \frac{d_{ij}}{n_i} \] \[ \bar d = \Sigma^{n}_{=1} \frac{d_i}{n} \] \[ s_i^2 = \Sigma_{j=1}^{n_i} \frac{(d_{ij} - \bar d_i)^2}{n_i-1} \] Compute pooled estimate within subject error \[ s_{dw}^2 = \Sigma_{=1}^{n} [\frac{n_i-1}{N-n} \cdot s_i^2] \] Compute pooled estimate subject error \[ s^2_b = \Sigma_{=1}^n \frac{ (\bar d_i - \bar d)^2}{n-1} \] Compute harmonic mean replicate size \[ m_h = \frac{n}{\Sigma_{=1}^n m_i^{-1}} \] Compute SD difference \[ s_d^2 = s^2_b + (1+m_h^{-1}) \cdot s_{dw}^2 \] Calculate LME MOVER Method \[ u = s_d^2 + \sqrt{[s_d^2 \cdot (1 - \frac{n-1}{\chi^2_{(1-\alpha, n-1)}})]^2+[(1-m_h^{-1}) \cdot (1- \frac{N-n}{\chi^2_{(1-\alpha, N-n)}})]^2} \] \[ LME = \sqrt{\frac{z_{\alpha} \cdot s_d^2}{n} + z_{\beta/2}^2 \cdot (\sqrt{u}-\sqrt{s^2_d} )^2} \] Bland-Altman Method \[ S_{LoA}^2 = \frac{s^2_d}{n} + \frac{z_{1-agree}^2}{2 \cdot s_d^2} \cdot (\frac{S_d^2}{n-1} + (1-\frac{1}{m_{xh}})^2 \cdot \frac{S_{xw}^4}{N_x - n} + (1-\frac{1}{m_{yh}})^2 \cdot \frac{S_{yw}^4}{N_y - n}) \] \[ LME = z_{1-\alpha} \cdot S_{LoA} \] Calculate LoA \[ LoA_{lower} = \bar d - z_{\beta/2} \cdot s_d \] \[ LoA_{upper} = \bar d + z_{\beta/2} \cdot s_d \] Calculate LoA CI \[ Lower \space CI = LoA_{lower} - LME \] \[ Upper \space CI = LoA_{upper} + LME \]

text: Model linear mixed model (detailed ) fit estimate bias (mean difference) variance components (within subject variance). \[ \begin{aligned}   \operatorname{difference}_{}  &\sim N \left(\alpha_{j[]}, \sigma^2 \right) \\     \alpha_{j}  &\sim N \left(\mu_{\alpha_{j}}, \sigma^2_{\alpha_{j}} \right)     \text{, subject j = 1,} \dots \text{,J} \end{aligned} \] 2. Extract Components two variance components, (\(s_b^2\) \(s_w^2\) \(\sigma^2\) \(\sigma_{\alpha_j}^2\)), estimated model. sum (\(s_{total}^2\)) total variance, grand intercept represents bias (mean difference, \(\bar d\)). harmonic mean also calculated. \[ m_h = \frac{n}{\Sigma_{=1}^n m_i^{-1}} \] Compute LME MOVER Method \[ u_1 =   (s_b^2 \cdot ((n-1)/(\chi^2_{\alpha,n-1})-1))^2 \] \[ u_2 = ((1-1/m_h) \cdot s_w^2 \cdot ((N-n)/( \chi^2_{\alpha,N-n} -1))^2 \] \[ u = s_{total}^2 + \sqrt{u_1 + u_2} \] \[ LME = \sqrt{\frac{z^2_{\alpha} \cdot s_d^2}{n} + z^2_{\beta/2} \cdot(\sqrt{u} - \sqrt{s^2_d})^2} \] Bland-Altman Method \[ S_{LoA} = \frac{s_b^2}{n} + z_{agree}^2 / (2 \cdot s_{total}^2) \cdot ((s_b^2)^2/(n-1) + (1 - 1/m_h)^2 \cdot (s_{w}^2)^2/(N-n)) \] \[ LME = z_{1-\alpha} \cdot S_{LoA} \] Calculate LoA \[ LoA_{lower} = \bar d - z_{\beta/2} \cdot s_d \] \[ LoA_{upper} = \bar d + z_{\beta/2} \cdot s_d \] Calculate LoA CI \[ Lower \space CI = LoA_{lower} - LME \] \[ Upper \space CI = LoA_{upper} + LME \]

text: vignette provides comprehensive guidance power analysis sample size determination method comparison agreement studies using SimplyAgree package.

title: Power Analysis and Sample Size Determination for Agreement Studies
text: SimplyAgree implements four approaches power/sample size calculations: power_agreement_exact() - Exact agreement test (Shieh 2019) blandPowerCurve() - Bland-Altman power curves (Lu et al. 2016) agree_expected_half() - Expected half-width criterion (Jan Shieh 2018) agree_assurance() - Assurance probability criterion (Jan Shieh 2018)
code: library(SimplyAgree)

title: Power Analysis and Sample Size Determination for Agreement Studies
text: methods divide two categories: Hypothesis Testing (binary decision): power_agreement_exact() - Tests central proportion, essentially tolerance intevals, within maximal allowable difference blandPowerCurve() - Tests confidence intervals limits agreement fall within maximal allowable difference Estimation (quantifying precision): agree_expected_half() - Controls average CI half-width limits agreement agree_assurance() - Controls probability achieving target CI half-width limits agreement

title: Power Analysis and Sample Size Determination for Agreement Studies
text: Tests whether central P* proportion paired differences falls within maximal allowable difference [-delta, delta]. Hypotheses: H0: Methods disagree (central portion extends beyond bounds) H1: Methods agree (central portion within bounds)

title: Power Analysis and Sample Size Determination for Agreement Studies
text: Specify exactly three : n, delta, power, sigma.
code: power_agreement_exact(   n = NULL,           # Sample size   delta = NULL,       # Tolerance bound   mu = 0,            # Mean of differences   sigma = NULL,       # SD of differences   p0_star = 0.95,    # Central proportion (tolerance coverage)   power = NULL,       # Target power   alpha = 0.05       # Significance level )

title: Power Analysis and Sample Size Determination for Agreement Studies
text: Many studies clustered data multiple measurements per subject natural groupings (e.g., repeated measures, multi-center studies). Note, advice applies clustering situations replicate measures taken within measurement occasion (e.g., multiple measures time point wherein variation represent measurement error). Standard formulas assume independence1. Ignoring clustering can leads studies lack precision. knowledge, well developed methods accounting clustering sample size calculations agreement studies, use common approximation survey sampling multilevel modeling: design effect.

title: Power Analysis and Sample Size Determination for Agreement Studies
text: design effect (DEFF) quantifies loss efficiency due clustering: \[\text{DEFF} = 1 + (m - 1) \times \text{ICC}\] : m = observations per cluster ICC = intraclass correlation coefficient \(n_{ESS}\) = effective sample size Effect sample size: \[n_{\text{ESS}} = n_{\text{independent}} \times \text{DEFF}\]

title: Power Analysis and Sample Size Determination for Agreement Studies
text: ICC = proportion variance clusters: \[\text{ICC} = \frac{\sigma^2_{\text{}}}{\sigma^2_{\text{}} + \sigma^2_{\text{within}}}\]

title: Power Analysis and Sample Size Determination for Agreement Studies
text: Calculate independent sample size (using power function) Determine m (observations per cluster) Estimate ICC (pilot data, literature, theory) Calculate DEFF = 1 + (m-1)*ICC Inflate: n_total = n_indep * DEFF Calculate clusters: K = smallest integer greater equal (n_total / m) (.e., round n_total / m)

title: Power Analysis and Sample Size Determination for Agreement Studies
text: Result: Instead 34 independent pairs, need ~15 participants (45 total observations).
code:
# Step 1: Independent sample size result <- power_agreement_exact(   delta = 7, mu = 0.5, sigma = 2.5,   p0_star = 0.95, power = 0.80, alpha = 0.05 ) #> Maximum iterations reached in gamma computation n_indep <- result$n cat("Independent pairs needed:", n_indep, "
") #> Independent pairs needed: 34  # Step 2: Apply design effect m <- 3  # 3 measurements per participant ICC <- 0.15  # from pilot or literature DEFF <- 1 + (m - 1) * ICC cat("Design effect:", round(DEFF, 3), "
") #> Design effect: 1.3  # Step 3: Calculate participants needed n_ess <- ceiling(n_indep * DEFF) K <- ceiling(n_ess / m) cat("Total observations:", n_ess, "
") #> Total observations: 45 cat("Participants needed:", K, "
") #> Participants needed: 15

title: Power Analysis and Sample Size Determination for Agreement Studies
code: # Compare different ICC values n_indep <- 50 m <- 4  ICC_values <- c(0, 0.05, 0.10, 0.15, 0.20) for (ICC in ICC_values) {   DEFF <- 1 + (m - 1) * ICC   K <- ceiling(ceiling(n_indep * DEFF) / m)   cat(sprintf("ICC = %.2f: Need %d participants\n", ICC, K)) } #> ICC = 0.00: Need 13 participants #> ICC = 0.05: Need 15 participants #> ICC = 0.10: Need 17 participants #> ICC = 0.15: Need 19 participants #> ICC = 0.20: Need 20 participants

title: Power Analysis and Sample Size Determination for Agreement Studies
text: Good situations: Balanced designs (equal cluster sizes) Moderate ICC (0.01 - 0.30) Sufficient clusters (K >= 10) Simple two-level hierarchy Problematic: Highly unbalanced clusters high ICC (> 0.4) Small number clusters (K < 10) Complex correlation structures Multiple levels nesting complex designs, consider simulation-based power analysis consult statistician.

title: Power Analysis and Sample Size Determination for Agreement Studies
code:
# Study parameters sigma <- 3.3 delta <- 7 m <- 4  # measurements per participant ICC <- 0.15 dropout <- 0.20  # Step 1: Independent sample size result <- power_agreement_exact(   delta = delta, mu = 0, sigma = sigma,   p0_star = 0.95, power = 0.80, alpha = 0.05 ) #> Maximum iterations reached in gamma computation  # Step 2: Account for clustering DEFF <- 1 + (m - 1) * ICC n_total <- ceiling(result$n * DEFF) K_pre <- ceiling(n_total / m)  # Step 3: Account for dropout K_final <- ceiling(K_pre / (1 - dropout))  # Summary cat("Independent pairs:", result$n, "
") #> Independent pairs: 566 cat("Design effect:", round(DEFF, 3), "
") #> Design effect: 1.45 cat("Participants (no dropout):", K_pre, "
") #> Participants (no dropout): 206 cat("Participants to recruit:", K_final, "
") #> Participants to recruit: 258 cat("Total measurements:", K_final * m, "
") #> Total measurements: 1032

text: tolerance_limit function can used calculate “tolerance limits”. Typically 95% prediction interval calculated provides predicted difference two measuring systems 95% future measurements pairs. However, account sampling error also need estimate confidence prediction intervals, therefore calculate tolerance limits. , 95% tolerance limits 95% prediction interval, can conclude 5% probability (1-tolerance) tolerance limits contain true prediction interval/limit.

text: calculate tolerance using loa_lme function. need identify columns right information using diff, avg, condition, id arguments. select right data set using data argument. Lastly, specify specifics conditions limits calculated. specific analysis decided calculate 95% prediction intervals 95% tolerance limits, use percentile bootstrap confidence intervals. print table tolerance limits, least Trec post exercise, providing conclusion (poor agreement). code: # note: more accurate tolerance limits are given by tol_method = "perc" rec.post_tol = tolerance_limit(   data = df_rec.post,   x = "PM",   y = "AM",   id = "id",   condition = "trial_condition" ) print(rec.post_tol) #> Agreement between Measures (Difference: x-y) #> 95% Prediction Interval with 95% Tolerance Limits #>  #>  Condition  Bias          Bias CI Prediction Interval  Tolerance Limits #>    23C/5.5 0.255 [0.0803, 0.4297]   [-0.3245, 0.8345] [-0.5248, 1.0348] #>    33C/5.5 0.254 [0.0964, 0.4116]   [-0.3144, 0.8224] [-0.4978, 1.0058] #>    33C/7.5 0.181   [0.021, 0.341]   [-0.7101, 1.0721] [-1.4732, 1.8352] plot(rec.post_tol) rec.delta_tol = tolerance_limit(   x = "PM",   y = "AM",   condition = "trial_condition",   id = "id",   data = df_rec.delta )    rec.delta_tol #> Agreement between Measures (Difference: x-y) #> 95% Prediction Interval with 95% Tolerance Limits #>  #>  Condition   Bias           Bias CI Prediction Interval  Tolerance Limits #>    23C/5.5 -0.019   [-0.084, 0.046]   [-0.2345, 0.1965] [-0.3466, 0.3086] #>    33C/5.5  0.015 [-0.0625, 0.0925]   [-0.1874, 0.2174] [-0.2646, 0.2946] #>    33C/7.5 -0.059 [-0.1635, 0.0455]   [-0.2723, 0.1543] [-0.3517, 0.2337] # Plot Maximal Allowable Difference with delta argument plot(rec.delta_tol,      delta = .25)

title: Reliability Analysis
text: Another feature R package ability estimate reliability measurement. R package allows calculation Intraclass Correlation Coefficients (ICC), various standard errors (SEM, SEE, SEP), coefficient variation. underlying calculations (sans coefficient variation) based paper Weir (2005)1. fairly popular paper within field (kinesiology), hence inspiration creating function provides calculative approaches included within manuscript.

title: Reliability Analysis
text: package, test-retest reliability statistics can calculated reli_stats function. function allow data input long (multiple rows data subject) wide (one row subject column item/measure). long data form, column containing subject identifier (id), item number (item), measurements (measure) provided. function refer items similar measuring internal consistency questionnaire (just special case test-retest reliability). , item also refer time points, typically seen human performance settings test-retest reliability may evaluated course repeated visits laboratory. wide set TRUE columns containing measurements provided (e.g., c("value1","value2","value3")). demonstrate function, create data set wide format. Now, data set (dat), can use reli_stats function. function also generic print plot functions. output print provides coefficient variation, standard errors, table various intraclass correlation coefficients. Notice conclusions reliability measurement vary greatly based statistic reported. statistic report beyond current vignette, heavily detailed Weir (2005). However, within table columns model measures describe model used different ICCs intended measure, respectively. Also included results plot measurements across items (e.g., time points).
code: # Example from Shrout and Fleiss (1979), pg. 423   dat = data.frame(judge1 =                       c(9,6,8,7,10,6),                    judge2 =                       c(2,1,4,1,5,2),                    judge3 =                       c(5,3,6,2,6,4),                    judge4 =                       c(8,2,8,6,9,7)) test1 = reli_stats(   data = dat,   wide = TRUE,   col.names = c("judge1", "judge2", "judge3", "judge4") ) print(test1) #>  #> Coefficient of Variation (%):  19.1 #> Standard Error of Measurement (SEM):  1.01 #> Standard Error of the Estimate (SEE):  1.22 #> Standard Error of Prediction (SEP):  1.9 #>  #> Intraclass Correlation Coefficients with  95 % C.I. #>            Model         Measures  Type    ICC Lower CI Upper CI #> 1 one-way random        Agreement  ICC1 0.1657 -0.09672   0.6434 #> 2 two-way random        Agreement  ICC2 0.2898  0.04290   0.6911 #> 3  two-way fixed      Consistency  ICC3 0.7148  0.41184   0.9258 #> 4 one-way random   Avg. Agreement ICC1k 0.4428 -0.54504   0.8783 #> 5 two-way random   Avg. Agreement ICC2k 0.6201  0.15204   0.8995 #> 6  two-way fixed Avg. Consistency ICC3k 0.9093  0.73690   0.9804 plot(test1)

Agreement ICC1k 0.4428 -0.54504   0.8783 #> 5 two-way random   Avg. Agreement ICC2k 0.6201  0.15204   0.8995 #> 6  two-way fixed Avg. Consistency ICC3k 0.9093  0.73690   0.9804

title: Reliability Analysis
text: linear mixed model used calculations specified following: \[   Y_{} \sim\ N \left(\alpha_{j[],k[]}, \sigma^2 \right) \] \[     \alpha_{j}  \sim\ N \left(\mu_{\alpha_{j}}, \sigma^2_{\alpha_{j}} \right)     \text{, id j = 1,} \dots \text{,J} \] \[     \alpha_{k}  \sim\ N \left(\mu_{\alpha_{k}}, \sigma^2_{\alpha_{k}} \right)     \text{, items k = 1,} \dots \text{,K} \]

title: Reliability Analysis
text: Mean Squared Error (MSE) \[ MSE = \sigma^2 \] Variance Subjects \[ MSB = n_k \cdot \sigma^2_{\alpha j} + \sigma^2 \] Variance Items/Judges \[ MSJ = n_{j} \cdot \sigma^2_{\alpha_{k}} + \sigma^2 \] Variance Within Subjects/Participants \[ MSW = \sigma^2 + \sigma^2_{\alpha_{k}} \]

title: Reliability Analysis
text: \[ ICC_{(1,1)} = \frac{MSB - MSW}{MSB + (n_j-1) \cdot MSW} \] \[ ICC_{(2,1)} = \frac{MSB - MSE}{MSB+(n_j -1) \cdot MSE + n_j \cdot (MSJ - MSE) \cdot n^{-1}} \] \[ ICC(_{3,1)} = \frac{MSB - MSE}{MSB + (n_j -1) \cdot MSE} \] \[ ICC_{(1,k)} = \frac{MSB - MSW}{MSB} \] \[ ICC_{(2,k)} = \frac{MSB - MSW}{MSB + (MSJ - MSE) \cdot n_j^{-1}} \] \[ ICC_{(3,k)} = \frac{MSB - MSE}{MSB} \]

title: Reliability Analysis
text: \[ F =  \frac{MSB}{MSW} \] \[ df_{n} = n_j - 1 \] \[ df_{d} = n_j \cdot (n_k - 1) \] \[ F_{L} = \frac{F}{F_{(1 - \alpha, \space df_{n}, \space df_{d})}} \] \[ F_{U} = F \cdot F_{(1 - \alpha, \space df_{d}, \space df_{n})} \] \[ Lower \space CI = \frac{(F_L - 1)}{(F_L + (n_j - 1))} \] \[ Upper \space CI = \frac{(F_U - 1)}{(F_U + n_j - 1)} \]

title: Reliability Analysis
text: \[ F =  \frac{MSJ}{MSE} \] \[ vn = (n_k - 1) \cdot (n_j - 1) \cdot [(nj \cdot ICC_{(2,1)} \cdot F + n_j \cdot                                      (1 + (n_k - 1) \cdot ICC_{(2,1)}) - n_k \cdot ICC_{(2,1)})]^2 \] \[   vd = (n_j - 1) \cdot n_k^2 \cdot ICC_{(2,1)}^2 \cdot F^2 + (n_j \cdot (1 +                                                          (n_k - 1) \cdot ICC_{(2,1)}) - n_k \cdot ICC_{(2,1)})^2 \] \[   v = \frac{vn}{vd} \] \[   F_{L} = F_{(1 - \alpha, \space n_j-1, \space v)} \] \[   F_{U} = F_{(1 - \alpha, \space v, \space n_j - 1)} \] \[   Lower \space CI = \frac{n_j \cdot (MSB - F_U \cdot MSE)}{(F_U \cdot (n_k \cdot MSJ + (n_k \cdot n_j - n_k - n_j) \cdot MSE) + n_j \cdot MSB)} \] \[   Upper \space CI = \frac{n_j \cdot (MSB \cdot F_L - MSE)}{(n_k \cdot MSJ + (n_k \cdot n_j - n_k - n_j) \cdot MSE + n_j \cdot F_L \cdot MSB)} \]

title: Reliability Analysis
text: \[ F =  \frac{MSJ}{MSE} \] \[ df_{n} = n_j - 1 \] \[ df_{d} = (n_j-1) \cdot (n_k - 1) \] \[ F_{L} = \frac{F}{F_{(1 - \alpha, \space df_{n}, \space df_{d})}} \] \[ F_{U} = F \cdot F_{(1 - \alpha, \space df_{n}, \space df_{d})} \] \[ F3L <- F31/qf(1 - alpha, df21n, df21d) \] \[ F3U <- F31 * qf(1 - alpha, df21d, df21n) \] \[ Lower \space CI = (F3L - 1)/(F3L + n_k - 1) \] \[ Upper \space CI = (F3U - 1)/(F3U + n_k - 1) \]

title: Reliability Analysis
text: \[ F =  \frac{MSB - MSW}{MSB} \] \[ df_{n} = n_j - 1 \] \[ df_{d} = n_j \cdot (n_k - 1) \] \[ F_{L} = \frac{F}{F_{(1 - \alpha, \space df_{n}, \space df_{d})}} \] \[ F_{U} = F \cdot F_{(1 - \alpha, \space df_{d}, \space df_{n})} \] \[ Lower \space CI = 1-\frac{1}{F_L} \] \[ Upper \space CI = 1-\frac{1}{F_U} \]

title: Reliability Analysis
text: \[ F =  \frac{MSB - MSW}{MSB} \] \[ vn = (n_k - 1) \cdot (n_j - 1) \cdot [(nj \cdot ICC_{(2,k)} \cdot F + n_j \cdot                                      (1 + (n_k - 1) \cdot ICC_{(2,k)}) - n_k \cdot ICC_{(2,k)})]^2 \] \[   vd = (n_j - 1) \cdot n_k^2 \cdot ICC_{(2,k)}^2 \cdot F^2 + (n_j \cdot (1 +                                                          (n_k - 1) \cdot ICC_{(2,k)}) - n_k \cdot ICC_{(2,k)})^2 \] \[ v = \frac{vn}{vd} \] \[ F_{L} = F_{(1 - \alpha, \space n_j-1, \space v)} \] \[ F_{U} = F_{(1 - \alpha, \space v, \space n_j - 1)} \] \[ L3 = \frac{n_j \cdot (MSB - F_U \cdot MSE)}{(F_U \cdot (n_k \cdot MSJ + (n_k \cdot n_j - n_k - n_j) \cdot MSE) + n_j \cdot MSB)} \] \[ U3 = \frac{n_j \cdot (MSB \cdot F_L - MSE)}{(n_k \cdot MSJ + (n_k \cdot n_j - n_k - n_j) \cdot MSE + n_j \cdot F_L \cdot MSB)} \] \[ Lower \space CI = \frac{L3 \cdot n_k}{(1 + L3 \cdot (n_k - 1))} \] \[ Upper \space CI = \frac{U3 \cdot n_k}{(1 + U3 \cdot (n_k - 1))} \]

title: Reliability Analysis
text: \[ F = \frac{MSB}{MSE} \] \[ df_n = n_j - 1 \] \[ df_d = (n_j - 1) \cdot (n_k - 1) \] \[ F_L = \frac{F}{F_{(1 - \alpha, \space df_n, \space df_d})} \] \[ F_U = F \cdot F_{(1 - \alpha, \space df_d, \space df_n)} \] \[ Lower \space CI = 1-\frac{1}{F_L} \] \[ Upper \space CI = 1-\frac{1}{F_U} \]

title: Reliability Analysis
text: standard error measurement (SEM), standard error estimate (SEE), standard error prediction (SEP) estimated following calculations.2 default SEM calculation following: \[ SEM = \sqrt{MSE} \] Alternatively, SEM can calculated following ICC determined se_type argument: \[ SEM = \sqrt{\frac{SS_{total}}{(N-1)}} \cdot \sqrt{1-ICC} \] measures default using following equations. default use \(ICC_{3,1}\), can modified se_type argument. \[ SEE = \sqrt{\frac{SS_{total}}{(N-1)}} \cdot \sqrt{ICC \cdot (1-ICC)} \] \[ SEP = \sqrt{\frac{SS_{total}}{(N-1)}} \cdot \sqrt{1-ICC^2} \]

title: Reliability Analysis
text: CV calculated 3 potential ways within reli_stats. highly recommend reporting default version CV. MSE (default) \[ CV = \frac{ \sqrt{MSE} }{ \bar y} \] SEM3 \[ CV = \frac{SEM}{ \bar y} \] model residuals (liberal) \[ CV = \frac{\sqrt{\frac{\Sigma^{N}_{=1}(y_i - \hat y_i)^2}{N_{obs}}}}{ \bar y} \]

title: Reliability Analysis
text: other_ci argument set TRUE confidence intervals calculated CV, SEM, SEP, SEE.

title: Reliability Analysis
text: default method type = 'chisq. method utilizes chi-square distribution approximate confidence intervals measurements. accuracy estimates likely variable, probably poor small samples. CV, calculation follows: \[ Lower \space CI = \frac{CV}{\sqrt{(\frac{\chi^2_{1-\alpha/2}}{df_{error}+1}-1) \cdot CV^2 \cdot \frac{\chi^2_{1-\alpha/2}}{df_{error}}}} \] \[ Upper \space CI = \frac{CV}{\sqrt{(\frac{\chi^2_{\alpha/2}}{df_{error}+1}-1) \cdot CV^2 \cdot \frac{\chi^2_{\alpha/2}}{df_{error}}}} \] variance based measures (s) calculation follows: \[ Lower \space CI = s \cdot \sqrt{\frac{df_{error}}{\chi^2_{1-\alpha/2}}} \] \[ Upper \space CI = s \cdot \sqrt{\frac{df_{error}}{\chi^2_{\alpha/2}}} \]

title: Reliability Analysis
text: type set chisq bootstrapping performed. reli_aov utilizes non-parametric ordinary bootstrap. reli_stats utilizes parametric bootstrap. number resamples can set replicates argument (default 1999; increase greater accuracy lower greater speed). reported confidence intervals estimated using percentile method type = 'perc', normal type = 'norm', basic methods type = 'basic'. ensure reproducibility, please use set.seed() confidence intervals calculated.

title: Reliability Analysis
text: cases, reliability categorical ordinal scale may worth investigating. example, physicians may want develop diagnosis tool ensure diagnosis reliable (.e., categorical designation) severity disease (.e., Likert-type scale). Coefficients can calculated assess degree inter-rater reliability. simplest form, percent agreement raters can calculated. coefficients agreement essentially trying “correct” random guessing rater. function make calculations SimplyAgree agree_coef, produces 4 estimates: percent agreement, Gwet’s AC, Fleiss’ Kappa, Krippendorff’s Alpha. However, packages provide much much greater breadth calculative approaches (Gwet 2019). agree_coef function, user can specify weighted = TRUE. argument set true ratings quadratic weights applied . Essentially, penalizes values farther away close . example, pair values equal 3 4 penalized less pair values 1 4. details, “agreement coefficients” refer users Gwet’s textbook inter-rater agreement (Gwet 2014). demonstration, can create matrix ratings. can perform analysis without weights. , perform weighting.
code: ratermat1 = ("Rater1 Rater2 Rater3 Rater4 1       1      1     NA      1 2       2      2      3      2 3       3      3      3      3 4       3      3      3      3 5       2      2      2      2 6       1      2      3      4 7       4      4      4      4 8       1      1      2      1 9       2      2      2      2 10     NA      5      5      5 11     NA     NA      1      1 12     NA     NA      3     NA")    ratermat2 = as.matrix(read.table(textConnection(ratermat1),                        header=TRUE,                        row.names=1)) agree_coef(data = ratermat2,                      wide = TRUE,                      weighted = FALSE,                      col.names = c("Rater1", "Rater2", "Rater3", "Rater4")) #>                              est        se  lower.ci upper.ci #> Percent Agreement      0.8181818 0.1256090 0.5417184        1 #> Gwet's AC1             0.7754441 0.1429500 0.4608133        1 #> Fleiss' Kappa          0.7611693 0.1530192 0.4243763        1 #> Kririppendorff's Alpha 0.7434211 0.1454787 0.4192743        1 agree_coef(data = ratermat2,                     wide = TRUE,                     weighted = TRUE,                     col.names = c("Rater1", "Rater2", "Rater3", "Rater4")) #>                              est         se  lower.ci upper.ci #> Percent Agreement      0.9753788 0.09061628 0.7759337        1 #> Gwet's AC2             0.9140007 0.10396224 0.6851814        1 #> Fleiss' Kappa          0.8649351 0.14603361 0.5435173        1 #> Kririppendorff's Alpha 0.8491071 0.12905120 0.5615632        1

title: Assurance Probability for Limits of Agreement — agree_assurance
text: object class "power.htest" containing following components: n: required sample size (number subject pairs) conf.level: confidence level (1 - alpha) assurance: target assurance probability (1 - gamma) actual.assurance: actual assurance probability achieved (may differ slightly target due discrete nature n) omega: upper bound assurance half-width pstar: central proportion covered (P*) sigma: population standard deviation g.factor: Odeh-Owen factor (g”) used construct tolerance interval, tabulated Odeh Owen (1980) method: Description method used note: Additional notes analysis

title: Assurance Probability for Limits of Agreement — agree_assurance
text: Calculate sample size necessary confidence interval Bland-Altman range agreement underlying data distribution normal. function uses assurance probability criterion determine optimum sample size, based exact confidence interval method Jan Shieh (2018), shown superior approximate methods.

title: Assurance Probability for Limits of Agreement — agree_assurance
text: function implements exact method determining sample size based assurance probability Bland-Altman limits agreement, described Jan Shieh (2018). assurance probability criterion determines N guarantees specified probability (1 - gamma) confidence interval half-width boundary value omega.

title: Assurance Probability for Limits of Agreement — agree_assurance
text: Suppose study involves paired differences (X - Y) whose distribution approximately N(mu, sigma^2). range agreement defined confidence interval central portion differences, specifically area 100(1-p)th 100p-th percentiles, p* = 2p - 1. exact two-sided, 100(1 - alpha)% confidence interval range agreement defined : Pr(theta_(1-p) < theta_hat_(1-p) theta_hat_p < theta_p) = 1 - alpha equal-tailed tolerance interval recommended Jan Shieh (2018) : (X_bar - d, X_bar + d) d = g * S, g Odeh-Owen tolerance factor (tabulated g” Odeh Owen (1980)), S sample standard deviation.

title: Assurance Probability for Limits of Agreement — agree_assurance
text: sample size N selected satisfy: Pr(H <= omega) >= 1 - gamma leads expression: psi(eta) >= 1 - gamma psi() CDF chi-square distribution N-1 degrees freedom eta = (N-1) \* (omega/(g\*sigma))^2. method uses equal-tailed tolerance intervals based noncentral t-distribution construct exact confidence intervals range agreement. tolerance factor g calculated interval maintains specified confidence level normality. Jan Shieh (2018) demonstrated extensive simulations exact method adopted rather classical Bland-Altman approximate method.

title: Assurance Probability for Limits of Agreement — agree_assurance
text: subject produces two measurements (one method compared). sample size n returned number subject pairs needed. actual assurance probability may differ slightly target due discrete nature sample size. dropout considerations, inflate sample size using: N' = N / (1 - dropout_rate), always rounding .

title: Sample Size for Limits of Agreement Using Expected Half-Width — agree_expected_half
text: Suppose study involves paired differences (X - Y) whose distribution approximately N(mu, sigma^2). range agreement defined confidence interval central portion differences, specifically area 100(1-p)th 100p-th percentiles, p* = 2p - 1. exact two-sided, 100(1 - alpha)% confidence interval range agreement defined : Pr(theta_(1-p) < theta_hat_(1-p) theta_hat_p < theta_p) = 1 - alpha equal-tailed tolerance interval recommended Jan Shieh (2018) : (X_bar - d, X_bar + d) d = g * S, g Odeh-Owen tolerance factor (tabulated g” Odeh Owen (1980) Hahn Meeker (1991)), S sample standard deviation.

title: Sample Size for Limits of Agreement Using Expected Half-Width — agree_expected_half
text: sample size N selected satisfy: E(H) <= delta H half-width confidence interval. leads expression: g(P*, 1-alpha, N-1) / c <= delta / sigma c bias correction factor: c = (Gamma((N-1)/2) * sqrt((N-1)/2)) / Gamma(N/2) expected half-width E(H) = (g/c) * sigma. accounts fact sample standard deviation S biased estimator sigma, requiring correction computing expected values. method uses equal-tailed tolerance intervals based noncentral t-distribution construct exact confidence intervals range agreement. tolerance factor g calculated interval maintains specified confidence level normality.

title: Simulate Deming Regression Power — deming_power
text: n_sims Number simulation iterations. Default 1000. sample_size Sample size (number paired observations) per simulation. x_range Numeric vector length 2 specifying min max X values (e.g., c(10, 100)). x_dist Character specifying distribution X values: "uniform", "central", "right_skewed". actual_slope Actual slope used generate data (e.g., 1.05 5% proportional bias). actual_intercept Actual intercept used generate data. ideal_slope Hypothesized slope test (typically 1 identity line). ideal_intercept Hypothesized intercept test (typically 0 identity line). y_var_params List Y variance parameters: beta1, beta2, J, type. Type can "constant", "proportional", "power". power function: sigma^2 = (beta1 + beta2*U)^J x_var_params List X variance parameters (structure y_var_params). weighted Logical. Use weighted Deming regression? Default FALSE. conf.level Confidence level tests. Default 0.95.

title: Simulate Deming Regression Power — deming_power
text: list class "deming_power" containing: power_ci_slope Power based slope confidence interval power_ci_intercept Power based intercept confidence interval power_either_ci Power either CI detects difference power_joint Power based joint confidence region settings List simulation settings advantage Difference power joint region CIs

title: Simulate Deming Regression Power — deming_power
text: Power Analysis Deming Regression function generates simulated datasets specified error characteristics tests whether confidence intervals joint confidence regions detect deviations hypothesized values. joint confidence region typically provides higher statistical power, especially X-range narrow (high slope-intercept correlation). variance functions allow flexible modeling heteroscedastic errors: constant: sigma^2 = beta1 proportional: sigma^2 = beta1 * U^2 (constant CV%) power: sigma^2 = (beta1 + beta2*U)^J

title: Simulate Deming Regression Power — deming_power

title: Passing-Bablok Regression for Method Comparison — pb_reg
text: formula formula form y ~ x specifying model. data Data frame data. id Column subject identifier (optional). provided, measurement error ratio calculated replicate measurements. method Method Passing-Bablok estimation. Options : "scissors": Scissors estimator (1988) - robust, scale invariant (default) "symmetric": Original Passing-Bablok (1983) - symmetric around 45-degree line "invariant": Scale-invariant method (1984) - adaptive reference line conf.level confidence level required. Default 95%. weights optional vector case weights used fitting process. NULL numeric vector. error.ratio Ratio measurement error variances (var(x)/var(y)). Default 1. argument ignored subject identifiers provided via id. replicates Number bootstrap iterations confidence intervals. 0 (default), analytical confidence intervals used. Bootstrap recommended weighted data 'invariant' 'scissors' methods. model Logical. TRUE (default), model frame stored returned object. needed methods like plot(), fitted(), residuals(), predict() work without supplying data. FALSE, model frame stored (saves memory large datasets), methods require data argument. keep_data Logical indicator (TRUE/FALSE). TRUE, intermediate calculations returned; default FALSE. ... Additional arguments (currently unused).

title: Passing-Bablok Regression for Method Comparison — pb_reg
text: function returns simple_eiv object following components: coefficients: Named vector coefficients (intercept slope). residuals: Residuals fitted model. fitted.values: Predicted Y values. model_table: Data frame presenting full results Passing-Bablok regression. vcov: Variance-covariance matrix slope intercept (bootstrap used). df.residual: Residual degrees freedom. call: matched call. terms: terms object used. model: model frame. x_vals: Original x values used fitting. y_vals: Original y values used fitting. weights: Case weights (provided). error.ratio: Error ratio used fitting. conf.level: Confidence level used. method: Character string describing method. method_num: Numeric method identifier (1, 2, 3). kendall_test: Results Kendall's tau correlation test. cusum_test: Results CUSUM linearity test. n_slopes: Number slopes used estimation. boot: Bootstrap results (replicates > 0).

title: Passing-Bablok Regression for Method Comparison — pb_reg
text: Passing-Bablok regression robust nonparametric method estimates slope shifted median possible slopes pairs points. intercept calculated median y - slope*x. method particularly useful : X Y measured error want robust method sensitive outliers relationship assumed linear X Y highly positively correlated

title: Passing-Bablok Regression for Method Comparison — pb_reg
text: Three Passing-Bablok methods available: "scissors" (default): scissors estimator (1988), robust scale-invariant. Uses median absolute values angles. "symmetric": original method (1983), symmetric y = x line. Uses line y = -x reference partitioning points. "invariant": Scale-invariant method (1984). First finds median angle slopes horizontal, uses reference line.

title: Passing-Bablok Regression for Method Comparison — pb_reg
text: data measured replicates, measurement error ratio can directly derived data. can accomplished indicating subject identifier id argument. replicates available data, ratio error variances (var(x)/var(y)) can provided error.ratio argument (default = 1, indicating equal measurement errors). error ratio affects pairwise slopes weighted robust median calculation. error.ratio = 1, pairs receive equal weight. error.ratio != 1, pairs weighted account heterogeneous measurement precision.

title: Passing-Bablok Regression for Method Comparison — pb_reg
text: Case weights can provided via weights argument. distinct measurement error weighting (controlled error.ratio). Case weights allow -weight -weight specific observations analysis.

title: Passing-Bablok Regression for Method Comparison — pb_reg
text: Wild bootstrap resampling used replicates > 0. particularly useful : Weighted regression (case weights error.ratio != 1) Methods 'invariant' 'scissors' (analytical CI validity uncertain) Small sample sizes method automatically: Tests high positive correlation using Kendall's tau Tests linearity using CUSUM test Computes confidence intervals (analytical bootstrap)

Passing, H. Bablok, W. (1984). Comparison several regression procedures method comparison studies determination sample sizes. Journal Clinical Chemistry Clinical Biochemistry, 22, 431-445. title: Passing-Bablok Regression for Method Comparison — pb_reg
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Basic Passing-Bablok regression (scissors method, default) model <- pb_reg(method2 ~ method1, data = mydata)  # With known error ratio model_er <- pb_reg(method2 ~ method1, data = mydata, error.ratio = 2)  # With replicate measurements model_rep <- pb_reg(method2 ~ method1, data = mydata, id = "subject_id")  # With bootstrap confidence intervals model_boot <- pb_reg(method2 ~ method1, data = mydata,                      error.ratio = 1.5, replicates = 1000)  # Symmetric method model_sym <- pb_reg(method2 ~ method1, data = mydata, method = "symmetric")  # Scale-invariant method model_inv <- pb_reg(method2 ~ method1, data = mydata, method = "invariant")  # With case weights model_wt <- pb_reg(method2 ~ method1, data = mydata,                    weights = mydata$case_weights)  # View results print(model) summary(model) plot(model) } # }

title: Power Calculation for Exact Agreement/Tolerance Test — power_agreement_exact
text: Computes sample size, power, parameters exact method assessing agreement two measurement methods, described Shieh (2019). method tests whether central portion paired differences falls within specified bounds. roughly equates power tolerance limits.

title: Power Calculation for Exact Agreement/Tolerance Test — power_agreement_exact
code: power_agreement_exact(   n = NULL,   delta = NULL,   mu = 0,   sigma = NULL,   p0_star = 0.95,   power = NULL,   alpha = 0.05,   max_iter = 1000 )

title: Power Calculation for Exact Agreement/Tolerance Test — power_agreement_exact
text: n Number subject pairs (sample size) delta Maximum allowable difference bound (half-width tolerance interval) mu Mean paired differences sigma Standard deviation paired differences p0_star coverage proportion (content) tolerance interval. Central proportion null hypothesis (default = 0.95) power Target power (probability rejecting false null) alpha Significance level (Type error rate, default = 0.05, Confidence level = 1-alpha) max_iter Maximum iterations gamma computation (default = 1000)

title: Power Calculation for Exact Agreement/Tolerance Test — power_agreement_exact
text: object class "power.htest", list components: n Sample size delta c mu Mean differences sigma Standard deviation differences p0_star Central proportion (null hypothesis) p1_star Central proportion (alternative hypothesis) alpha Significance level power Power test critical_value Critical value test statistic method Description method note Additional notes

title: Power Calculation for Exact Agreement/Tolerance Test — power_agreement_exact
text: function implements exact agreement test procedure Shieh (2019) method comparison studies. test evaluates whether central proportion distribution paired differences lies within interval [-delta, delta]. null hypothesis : H0: theta_(1-p) <= -delta delta <= theta_p alternative : H1: -delta < theta_(1-p) theta_p < delta p = (1 + p0_star)/2, theta_p represents 100p-th percentile paired differences. Specify three : n, delta, power, sigma. fourth calculated. mu specified, defaults 0. Tolerance Interval Interpretation: parameter p0_star represents tolerance coverage proportion, .e., proportion population must fall within specified bounds [-delta, delta] null hypothesis. conceptually related tolerance intervals, formulated hypothesis test rather estimation problem. Note: differs Bland-Altman's "95% limits agreement," confidence intervals 2.5th 97.5th percentiles, tolerance intervals.

title: Power Calculation for Exact Agreement/Tolerance Test — power_agreement_exact
text: Shieh, G. (2019). Assessing Agreement Two Methods Quantitative Measurements: Exact Test Procedure Sample Size Calculation. Statistics Biopharmaceutical Research, 12(3), 352-359. https://doi.org/10.1080/19466315.2019.1677495

title: Power Calculation for Exact Agreement/Tolerance Test — power_agreement_exact

Two measurements per unit; one for each method. #>   # Example 2: Calculate power for given sample size power_agreement_exact(n = 15, delta = 0.1, mu = 0.011,                       sigma = 0.044, p0_star = 0.80, alpha = 0.05) #>  #>      Power for Exact Method for Assessing Agreement Between Two Methods  #>  #>               n = 15 #>           delta = 0.1 #>              mu = 0.011 #>           sigma = 0.044 #>         p0_star = 0.8 #>         p1_star = 0.9726269 #>           alpha = 0.05 #>           power = 0.8315332 #>  critical_value = 6.391135 #>  #> NOTE: H0: Central 80% of differences not within [-delta, delta] #>      H1: Central 97.3% of differences within [-delta, delta]  #> n is number pairs. Two measurements per unit; one for each method. #>   # Example 3: Find required delta for given power and sample size power_agreement_exact(n = 50, mu = 0, sigma = 2.5,                       p0_star = 0.95, power = 0.90, alpha = 0.05) #>  #>      Power for Exact Method for Assessing Agreement Between Two Methods  #>  #>               n = 50 #>           delta = 6.65619 #>              mu = 0 #>           sigma = 2.5 #>         p0_star = 0.95 #>         p1_star = 0.9922432 #>           alpha = 0.05 #>           power = 0.9000104 #>  critical_value = 15.89319 #>  #> NOTE: H0: Central 95% of differences not within [-delta, delta] #>      H1: Central 99.2% of differences within [-delta, delta]  #> n is number pairs. title: Tolerance Limits from an Agreement Study — tolerance_limit
text: function calculating tolerance limits difference two measurements (difference = x-y). procedure produce results similar Bland-Altman limits agreement. See vignettes details.

title: Tolerance Limits from an Agreement Study — tolerance_limit
code: tolerance_limit(   data,   x,   y,   id = NULL,   condition = NULL,   time = NULL,   pred_level = 0.95,   tol_level = 0.95,   tol_method = c("approx", "perc"),   prop_bias = FALSE,   log_tf = FALSE,   log_tf_display = c("ratio", "sympercent"),   cor_type = c("sym", "car1", "ar1", "none"),   correlation = NULL,   weights = NULL,   keep_model = TRUE,   replicates = 999 )

title: Tolerance Limits from an Agreement Study — tolerance_limit
text: data data frame containing variables. x Name column first measurement. y Name column second measurement. id Name column subject ID. condition Name column indicating different conditions subjects tested . can left missing differing conditions tested. time Name column indicating time points. necessary data time series repeated measures collection. pred_level Prediction level prediction interval. Default 95%. tol_level Tolerance level tolerance limit (.e., CI prediction limit). Default 95%. tol_method Method calculating tolerance interval. Options "approx" chi-square based approximation "perc" parametric percentile bootstrap method. prop_bias Whether include proportional bias term model. Determines whether proportional bias considered prediction/tolerance limits calculations. log_tf Calculate limits agreement using log-transformed data. log_tf_display type presentation log-transformed results. differences methods can displayed "ratio" "sympercent". cor_type type correlation structure. "sym" Compound Symmetry, "car1" continuous autocorrelation structure order 1, "ar1" autocorrelation structure order 1. correlation optional corStruct object describing within-group correlation structure overrides default setting. See documentation corClasses description available corStruct classes. grouping variable used, must specified form argument corStruct constructor. Defaults NULL. weights optional varFunc object one-sided formula describing within-group heteroskedasticity structure overrides default setting. given formula, used argument varFixed, corresponding fixed variance weights. See documentation varClasses description available varFunc classes. keep_model Logical indicator retain GLS model. Useful working large data model large. replicates number bootstrap replicates. Passed boot function. Default 999.

title: Tolerance Limits from an Agreement Study — tolerance_limit
text: Returns single tolerance_delta class object results agreement analysis prediction interval tolerance limits. limits: data frame containing prediction/tolerance limits. model: GLS model; NULL keep_model set FALSE. call: matched call.

title: Tolerance Limits from an Agreement Study — tolerance_limit
text: tolerance limits calculated function based papers Francq & Govaerts (2016), Francq, et al. (2019), Francq, et al. (2020). tol_method set "approx", tolerance limits calculated using approximation detailed Francq et al. (2020). However, approximation conservative. Therefore, suggested Francq, et al. (2019), parametric bootstrap approach can utilized calculate percentile tolerance limits (tol_method = "perc").

title: Tolerance Limits from an Agreement Study — tolerance_limit
text: Francq, B. G., & Govaerts, B. (2016). regress predict Bland–Altman plot? Review contribution based tolerance intervals correlated‐errors‐‐variables models. Statistics mMdicine, 35(14), 2328-2358. Francq, B. G., Lin, D., & Hoyer, W. (2019). Confidence, prediction, tolerance linear mixed models. Statistics Medicine, 38(30), 5603-5622. Francq, B. G., Berger, M., & Boachie, C. (2020). tolerate agree: tutorial tolerance intervals method comparison studies BivRegBLS R Package. Statistics Medicine, 39(28), 4334-4349.
